p: The Chicago example notwithstanding, cities tend to invest in visible, tangible, hard infrastructure rather than soft vulnerability reduction measures, often generating unintended consequences in the process. After a major flood in 1962, Norfolk, Virginia built a large sea wall rather than reduce residents' exposure by using buyouts and insurance to encourage them to relocate away from low‐lying areas, which remain highly vulnerable to sea‐level rise (National Research Council, 2004; Norfolk, Virginia, City of, n.d.). This is an example of the “safe development paradox,” where “increased safety induces increased development leading to increased losses” (Kates, Colten, Laska, & Leatherman, 2006, p. 14653; see also Adger et al., 2005).
